ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I became more confident in my Spanish speaking and gained new knowledge about the culture of Spanish-speaking countries, especially with respect to indigenous cultures.

General improvement in speaking and understanding of Spanish culture. We discussed many important current issues like the perpetual effects of colonialism in Latin American countries, the expression of sexism and social issues in artistic interventions, and the use of the idea of humanity to justify attacks on the environment.
I improved my ability to understand, speak, and write Spanish. This course also focused more on hispanic/Latin American culture, unlike SPAN 130 which was more focused on grammar.
I learned how to read and write more smoothly in Spanish, and practiced speech and accents.

I gained the ability to speak Spanish better and think of words quickly. This was difficult for me before taking the class. I used to think of what I wanted to say in English and then translate it in my mind before speaking.
Speaking, writing, listening in Spanish
I gained a better understanding of Spanish culture and language.
I learned listening and reading comprehension, writing proficiency in spanish, and spanish/indigenous culture.

I particulary learned how to speak, write, produce videos in Spanish related to topics of decolonizing the gaze, idigeniety, and the complex immigrant experience. I had never taken a Spanish class like this before and I was pleased to develop my Spanish skills in such an analytical and academic context.
Culture, grammar, better grasp of language
My ability to speak, read, write, and comprehend Spanish improved. We studied a variety of topics relating to the cultures of Spanish speaking countries or broader societal issues.
Become more aware of Spanish culture and gained a greater control over my Spanish.
I was able to develop my Spanish in term of grammar, fluency, and overall competency

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was the first Spanish course that I took that went into great detail about the history of women and indigenous communities in Spanish-speaking countries. Some strengths were that we got to delve deep into examples, but some weaknesses were that we only covered a few examples for each chapter.

I loved this course overall, mostly because of Sebastian. Although I really enjoyed the group projects, I wish there had been a greater variety of projects rather than just videos, because in many of these video projects one of the people who knew how to use iMovie or TikTok would carry the whole thing. However, I enjoyed the course material and through the peer work in class I made many good friends.

Strengths -- a lot of different assignments that engage different skills (speaking, writing, etc). Meets frequently which helps with learning. Weaknesses -- compared to last semester, participation was not as heavily encouraged. At times it felt like corrections while speaking were more like getting cut off.
This course was strong in the aspects where it tried to go beyond simple grammar and focus on overall fluency.

The main strength of this class was group projects, as I was able to connect with other students. I also enjoyed talking about my weekend in Spanish with my classmates. As a Christian student, however, I did not enjoy the unit on witchcraft.
repetitive
I liked that there were no tests and I enjoyed the projects. The topics in class were interesting.

The professor was a strength as he was very enthusiastic about the course and had a passion for teaching. Things that could be improved were some days that included busy work that felt tedious at times.
One particular strength of the course are the many ways in which we practice our writing. I also appreciated beiong able to develop our own interests in the individual projects!
More talking. Some of the subjects touched upon were very complex and I didnt have the vocabulary to talk about them

The weakness of this course is something that applies to many language classes at Yale: it meets almost every day. This means that there is a lot of work (sometimes a lot of busy work). The strength of the course is the instructor. Professor Diaz was fantastic. He made the class interesting, gave helpful feedback, and was very helpful.

Strengths: lots of practice

Weaknesses: sometimes assignments felt like busy work. Grading can be variable at times.
Strengths: Professor Sebastian is great and really cares about all of his students learning. He invested in all of us and prioritized giving us individual feedback

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially a student who is looking to develop their Spanish proficiency.
Yes; I honestly enjoyed it more than Spanish 130. Although I will not be taking Spanish 150, this course had the potential of convincing me to continue.
Only to fulfill the language requirement
Yes, this was a good course that helped me continue on my Spanish learning journey.
I would recommend this course, as it focused on many cultural aspects rather than only grammar.
Yes if you need a language credit. I overall enjoyed the course
Yes, it was really immersive and engaging most of the time.
I would recommend this course to another student especially those that are undecided on what language to do
Its a good way to improve Spanish in a fun way.
Yes, if you need to complete your language requirement or want to learn Spanish. Particularly, take the class with Professor Diaz.
I would recommend this course if you really want to develop your Spanish and are willing to put in the work
Yes, it is a great way to learn Spanish.
Yes. Loved it. Diverse mix of material teaching language and culture.
